security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation and template skill with no executable code, network calls, or file system access. It contains only design system guidance, JSON token schemas, TypeScript component templates, and accessibility checklists.

content.user_title: Build Consistent Design Systems with Tokens and Components
content.value_statement: Creating consistent, accessible user interfaces across applications is challenging without standardized design foundations. This skill provides design token structures, component patterns, and accessibility guidelines to build scalable design systems that ensure visual consistency and WCAG compliance.
actual_capabilities: Define W3C-compliant design tokens for colors, typography, spacing, and shadows
Create accessible React components following atomic design methodology
Implement dark mode theming with CSS variables and semantic tokens
Apply WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessibility standards to all components
Build component documentation templates for Storybook or similar tools
limitations: Does not generate actual code files on disk
Does not connect to design tools like Figma or Sketch
Does not provide visual design or color palette recommendations

use_cases.title: Build Component Libraries
use_cases.description: Create reusable component libraries that ensure consistency across team projects.

use_cases.title: Establish Token Foundations
use_cases.description: Define design token structures and documentation for organization-wide design standards.

use_cases.title: Ensure Accessibility Compliance
use_cases.description: Apply WCAG guidelines to make applications accessible to all users.

prompt_templates.title: Create Design Tokens
prompt_templates.prompt: Create design tokens for our design system including color primitives (50-950 scale), semantic colors for brand and feedback, typography scale, and spacing scale. Use W3C format.

prompt_templates.title: Build Accessible Button
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an accessible Button component in React with primary, secondary, outline, and ghost variants. Include proper ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, focus states, and loading indicators.

prompt_templates.title: Implement Dark Mode
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement dark mode support for our design system using CSS variables. Include a theme toggle component that respects system preferences and persists user choice.

prompt_templates.title: Audit Accessibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Review our Modal component for WCAG 2.1 Level AA compliance. Check focus management, ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, and color contrast requirements.

best_practices: Start with foundational design tokens before building components
Implement accessibility features from the start, not as an afterthought
Document all components with usage examples, props API, and accessibility notes
anti_patterns: Mixing primitive and semantic tokens in component styling
Hardcoding color values instead of using design tokens
Skipping accessibility testing during component development

faq.question: Which frontend frameworks does this skill support?
faq.answer: The patterns work with React, Vue, Angular, and web components. Templates use React/TypeScript but concepts apply broadly.

faq.question: What accessibility standards are covered?
faq.answer: WCAG 2.1 Level AA compliance including color contrast, keyboard navigation, ARIA attributes, and screen reader support.

faq.question: Can I create multiple theme variants?
faq.answer: Yes, the token system supports light/dark themes and custom brand variants through semantic token mapping.

faq.question: Are the design tokens ready for production?
faq.answer: Yes, tokens follow W3C Design Token Community Group format and integrate with Style Dictionary and similar tools.

faq.question: What documentation formats are included?
faq.answer: Templates for Storybook, component README files, and a comprehensive design system checklist for audits.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing projects?
faq.answer: Copy tokens to your CSS variables or theme config. Use component templates as starting points for your codebase.
